text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits revised IRM 4.50.2, LB&I Compliance Integration, Other Workload Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Compliance Programs. This IRM describes the functions, tools, and systems for LB&I workload selection methods that are non-campaign-sourced.
IRM 4.50.2.1.6: Added additional treatment streams.
4.50.2.2.2.2: Removed Supplemental GHW Inventory Sources section due to duplication in IRM Global High Wealth Program Processes and Procedures.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
LB&I employees

Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Programs
) Purpose: This IRM provides an overview of LB&I non-campaign workload selection. (
) Audience: All LB&I employees. (
) Policy and Program Owner: LB&I Assistant Deputy Commissioner ance Integration. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Including, but not limited to, all geographic and matter practice areas in LB&I. (
) Program Goals: The overall program goal is to direct LB&I resources the highest compliance risks and to select the best work. (

) LB&I work processes are evolving to meet the needs of a rapidly changing taxpayer environment. This section describes the current state of workload identiﬁcation and selection from non-campaign-generated sources. (
) This IRM provides the authority to conduct research. The research extends all LB&I returns, including related forms and schedules. (
) Compliance Planning and Analytics (CP&A), is the responsible function in for all campaign (see IRM

) and non-campaign workload selection methods in LB&I. CP&A is responsible for establishing return coverage LB&I practice areas. This business unit is in the Assistant Deputy Commis- sioner Compliance Integration (ADCCI) organization. (
) CP&A also manages research requests (as described in IRM
) the practice areas in LB&I. (
) The non-campaign workload selection programs are described in IRM (

) Program Reports: Research studies include: • Conducting environmental scans on ﬁling information • Examining compliance of speciﬁc taxpayer segments • Developing mathematical models and expert systems to support selection (
) Business Performance Reports contain metrics used to gauge the ness of current workload selection methods and processes. (

) Program Effectiveness: The business objective for conducting research studies is to make informed decisions, drive compliance efforts and voluntary compliance by identifying and delivering the highest risk returns audit or by sending soft notices to ensure the methodology applied is to the IRS mission. The business objective for producing performance is to provide LB&I management with statistics and trends to evaluate the various workload selection activities.
Other Workload Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Compliance Programs 4.50.2
Purpose: This IRM provides an overview of LB&I non-campaign workload selection.
Program Goals: The overall program goal is to direct LB&I resources toward the highest compliance risks and to select the best work.
This IRM provides the authority to conduct research. The research extends to all LB&I returns, including related forms and schedules.
(04-22-2019) Program Management and Review
Business Performance Reports contain metrics used to gauge the effective- ness of current workload selection methods and processes.
4.50 LB&I Compliance Integration
LB&I Compliance (
) Separation of duties: See IRM
) Policy Statement
: See IRM
, Fairness and Integrity in En- forcement Selection. (
) Risk Identiﬁcation Control Board (RICB): The mission of RICB is to ensure the enforcement selection process is an equitable and fair process to all taxpayers under Policy Statement

RICB Part I and II approval is required before ﬁlters, models, and/or other workload selection criteria are used for workload selection. RICB approval is required for Part I to develop and test the selection model. RICB and the respective Practice Area approval are required on Part II to implement the model into a compliance program. See IRM
, LB&I Compliance Integration, Campaign Develop- ment Process, for more information on RICB. (

) RICB will only approve workload selection criteria based on tax laws and treasury regulations and not on organization names or their policy positions. The goal of RICB is to ensure that the criteria used for workload selection promotes public conﬁdence that tax laws are being applied impartially. (

) Research requests from the practice areas must be approved by the CP&A Director. CP&A is responsible for establishing workload selection across LB&I practice areas and in supporting research studies (see IRM

)) based on voluntary compliance objectives. The business objective for ing research studies is to drive compliance efforts and to improve voluntary compliance by identifying and delivering noncompliant returns to audit to ensure the methodology applied is aligned to the IRS mission. This IRM also provides the authority to conduct research. The research extends to all

, LB&I Compliance Integration, Campaign Development Process, for information about campaign-sourced workload selection. Resources for campaign work are the Campaign Quick Start Guide, the Campaign Process chart, and the LB&I Campaign Guide. (

) LB&I administers the following compliance programs: • Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) - See IRM
, Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) Examinations • Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) • Global High Wealth (GHW)/High Income Individual Entities (PTE) • Campaigns - See IRM

) The Large Corporate Compliance Program (LCC) is the successor program the Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) program. LCC employs a risk based selection process to address selected compliance risks in the large taxpayer population using a ﬁnite amount of resources, through the of one or more treatment streams to achieve the intended compliance outcomes.
(09-23-2021) Workload Selection Program Areas
Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) - See IRM
, Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) Examinations Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) Global High Wealth (GHW)/High Income Individual Entities (PTE) Campaigns - See IRM
, Campaign Development Process Foreign Payments Practice Mandatory Discretionary

The Large Corporate Compliance Program (LCC) is the successor program to the Coordinated Industry Case (CIC) program. LCC employs a risk based selection process to address selected compliance risks in the large corporate taxpayer population using a ﬁnite amount of resources, through the application of one or more treatment streams to achieve the intended compliance outcomes.

4.50.2.2.2 (07-26-2022) Global High Wealth (GHW)/High Income Individual (HII)/Pass-ThroughEntities(PTE)
) ADCCI has primary responsibility for overall coordination of the compliance plan and workload identiﬁcation with the exception of the GHW Model. (
) The Data Solutions Models team in ADCCI uses mathematical models for workload selection. Similar to the Campaign and LCC Programs, GHW models must be approved by the RICB. See IRM
, Program Controls. (

) The Pass-Through Entities Practice Area has the primary responsibility over the GHW/HII/PTE Compliance Program, which includes the processes and oversight required to identify, prioritize and allocate resources towards pass-
The Data Solutions Models team in ADCCI uses mathematical models for workload selection. Similar to the Campaign and LCC Programs, GHW models must be approved by the RICB. See IRM
, Program Controls.

) The GHW/HII/PTE program was formed to take a holistic approach in ing the high-income, high-wealth population, including consideration of items associated with pass-through returns. This program leverages data, applied analytics, algorithms and institutional experience to assess the compliance that these enterprises pose with their increasingly sophisticated tax strategies. (

) The GHW/HII/PTE program covers the entire business enterprise of entities controlled by high wealth individuals. These enterprises may include interests in partnerships, trusts, subchapter S corporations, private foundations and others. (

) In addition, under the GHW/HII/PTE program, LB&I will develop, test, and monitor mathematical and machine learning models to identify partnership and S corporation returns with examination potential.
LB&I Compliance (
) GHW consists of two functions: Workload Services (WLS) and ﬁeld tion groups. The GHW returns identiﬁed by the models are made available the WLS for classiﬁcation and risk assessment. (

) Partnership or S corporation returns identiﬁed under these models will be siﬁed and risk-assessed in Content Management and Collaboration (CMC). certain circumstances, Individual returns will also be classiﬁed and risk assessed in CMC. (

) An “enterprise” is deﬁned as a group of entities that are managed for the economic and tax beneﬁt of a controlling interest. Enterprise Risk uses the evaluation of multi-entity and multi-year related return groupings to determine what constitutes a single economic “enterprise.” (
) Models to be developed include: • Single return selection systems • Enterprise selection systems • Single year and/or multi-year models (

) Models will be developed using internal and external data sources. The tion of models and data ﬁelds will be analyzed and gathered from feedback and operational databases to monitor the model’s effectiveness in identifying the next best case. (
) See IRM
, Global High Wealth Program Processes and Procedures, more information. (
) See IRM
, Collateral Examinations. (

) The Foreign Payments Practice (FPP) includes the processes and oversight required to identify, prioritize and allocate resources towards foreign ing tax matters and foreign ﬁnancial institution compliance under Chapters
and
of the Internal Revenue Code. See IRM
, Foreign Payment Practice (FPP) Field Operations Overview. (

) The FPP provides oversight of non-resident alien withholding tax matters an emphasis on Service-wide coordination of technical issues, compliance, processing and other information relating to non-resident aliens. The FPP is also responsible for monitoring and enforcing compliance of foreign ﬁnancial institutions participating in the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act Program (FATCA). (

) The FPP focuses resources through coordinated development of information and educational material, improved forms and publications, processing bilities, examination strategies and other treatment streams to achieve intended compliance outcomes. (
) FPP identiﬁes compliance risks within the non-resident alien withholding lation. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The FPP is also responsible for monitoring and enforcing compliance of foreign ﬁnancial institutions participating in the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act Program (FATCA). (

LB&I Compliance (

) Transactions that have been determined by the Service to be tax avoidance transactions are “listed transactions”. As a result, taxpayers may need to disclose their participation in these listed transactions as prescribed in
CFR
, and material advisors may need to disclose these transactions
CFR
of the Procedure and Administration Regulations. Taxpayers who fail to disclose may be subject to penalties under IRC
A and IRC
A. Material advisors who fail to disclose may be subject to penalties under IRC
In addition, material advisors must maintain lists of advisees and other information with respect to these listed transactions pursuant to
CFR
Material advisors who fail to furnish a list as required under this regulation may be subject to penalties under IRC
) Notice
IRB

, contains the list of transactions that have been determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be “listed transactions”. See https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/listed-transactions for a chronological listing of listed transactions and recognized abusive In addition to the list of listed transactions described in Notice

, and the link referenced in the previous sentence, the link includes additional infor- mation related to some of the listed transactions including, but not limited to, settlement initiatives and Appeals Settlement Guidelines. (

) If the listed transaction surfaces during an examination, it must be raised as issue following the listing notice. Examiners should contact the subject matter expert and provide the name of the taxpayer, taxable period(s) involved, type of listed transaction, the name of the promoter, if known, the name and telephone number of the team/group Manager and, if applicable, the name telephone number of the team coordinator. The initial contact may be via e-mail (using secure messaging), fax or telephone. (

) Examiners should consult with subject matter experts and local area Counsel on the development of the issue. Examiners must secure the concurrence of the appropriate subject matter expert if their examination deviates from any mandated speciﬁc examination techniques proposed for issue development or their proposal for adjustment deviates from any stated legal positions. Examiners must also consult with and secure the concurrence of the appropri- ate subject matter expert and Counsel before proposing any resolution other than full concession of the issue by the taxpayer. No proposals can be made without the concurrence of the Issue Champion. (

) After initial publication of guidance identifying a listed transaction is released, the responsible division and Chief Counsel staff will meet to discuss the need to further develop the issue. The discussion will include whether there is a need for Counsel to provide a thorough legal analysis of the issue or other guidance. If additional guidance is needed, the group will decide what format should be used to issue the additional legal analysis. For example, the addi- tional legal analysis might take the form of a Chief Counsel Notice, a part of audit handbook/ techniques guide, or a revenue ruling. An Associate Chief Counsel will be assigned primary responsibility for preparing the additional legal analysis. That Associate office will work with the Issue Team on the analysis and coordinate with other Associates as necessary. The issue team should regularly coordinate with Chief Counsel staff during the development of the legal analysis.

If additional guidance is needed, the group will decide what format should be used to issue the additional legal analysis. For example, the addi- tional legal analysis might take the form of a Chief Counsel Notice, a part of an audit handbook/ techniques guide, or a revenue ruling. An Associate Chief Counsel will be assigned primary responsibility for preparing the additional legal analysis. That Associate office will work with the Issue Team on the analysis and coordinate with other Associates as necessary. The issue team should regularly coordinate with Chief Counsel staff during the development of the legal analysis.
Other Workload Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Compliance Programs 4.50.2

) The Discretionary Compliance Program includes, but is not limited to, the following. Some of these sources of work may be priority but not required to worked. • Training Returns • Claims • Bankruptcy • Information Referrals and Reports • Program Action Cases • Change in Accounting Method-Voluntary Change-Advance Consent • Emerging Issues • Transactions of Interest (

) LB&I uses workload selection criteria (models, ﬁlters, Discriminant Analysis System (DAS), etc.) to identify and allocate resources towards the ary program. Similar to all the other programs, workload selection criteria to identify discretionary work must be approved by the RICB. (
) LB&I Planning and Special Programs (PSP) in LB&I’s practice areas have primary responsibility for ordering LB&I returns using the LB&I Workload ﬁcation System (LWIS). (
) Project Code
, Training Return, should be applied to all returns and started during formal training. (
) All related, subsequent year, and/or prior year returns secured in connection with the training return will also have Project Code
assigned, provided they are started during formal training. (
) Formal training is deﬁned as scheduled, organized online or classroom and on-the-job training phase. (
) Training may include returns identiﬁed through other compliance programs such as campaigns. (
) Project code
should be removed from any key case return assigned during training but NOT started during training. (
) Claims for refund - LB&I taxpayers generally ﬁle claims for refund on Form
-X, Amended U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return, or Form
, ration Application for Tentative Refund. Also see IRM

, Claims, Abatements and Refunds. Claims related to returns already controlled by ﬁeld are not classiﬁed, but rather forwarded to the ﬁeld for association with controlled return(s). All other claims, (i.e., without open AIMS) that meet Category A criteria (IRM Exhibit
) are classiﬁed prior to processing. The classiﬁer may review and request other relevant returns. • Claims in excess of $
million for corporations are to be reviewed by Joint Committee Review per IRM
, Authority, and are to mandatory review per IRM

These claims must be and either surveyed or opened for examination. • All claims selected for examination are sent to SB/SE Classiﬁcation Control Unit (CCU). CCU updates the claim to Exam Organization

) Whistleblower Claims - LB&I receives whistleblower claims from the IRS Whistleblower Office and works these claims in accordance with established IRS policy. See IRM

, General Operating Division Guidance for Whistleblower Claims, for speciﬁc procedures on how to address claims. CP&A reviews and determines if whistleblower claims merit an nation. If the whistleblower claim merits an examination, CP&A will assign claim to the ﬁeld. (

) SB/SE Insolvency Unit will notify/forward any bankruptcy notiﬁcations or requests that are related to LB&I taxpayers to the LB&I Bankruptcy tor. These can include, but are not limited to, proof of claims and prompt determinations. Refer to IRM
, Bankruptcy, for detailed information on amination bankruptcy procedures. (
) The LB&I Bankruptcy coordinator requests and controls all returns needed determinations and presents them to the LB&I classiﬁer for classiﬁcation. (
) All selected returns will be coordinated through the practice area PSPs for signment to the ﬁeld. (
) All taxpayers are sent a notiﬁcation of selection or acceptance of the return the LB&I Bankruptcy coordinator for all LB&I prompt determination requests. (
) LB&I information referrals and reports originate from several different including Form
, Examination Information Report, Form
-A, tion Referral, federal and state agencies referrals, foreign government and public citizen referrals.

The LB&I Bankruptcy coordinator requests and controls all returns needed for determinations and presents them to the LB&I classiﬁer for classiﬁcation.
All taxpayers are sent a notiﬁcation of selection or acceptance of the return by the LB&I Bankruptcy coordinator for all LB&I prompt determination requests.
Other Workload Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Compliance Programs 4.50.2

Program Action Cases (PACs) are preparer investigations where clients of preparers of interest are examined to determine whether preparer and/or injunctive actions against the preparers are warranted. If a misconduct appears to be pervasive and not isolated to a single taxpayer, sideration should be given to opening a PAC. Information on the PAC approval process and return identiﬁcation and selection is found in IRM
, Return Preparer Program Coordinator. Return preparer penalties are described in IRM

, Penalty Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties. Any inquiry regarding a return preparer penalty or PAC should be referred the LB&I Return Preparer Coordinator (RPC), who is located in the Practice Network. Form
, Application for Change in Accounting Method (CAM), is ﬁled National Office and a copy attached to the taxpayer’s tax return in the change. National Office reviews the Form
and issues determination letters to taxpayers authorizing or denying a change in accounting
Information on the PAC approval process and return identiﬁcation and selection is found in IRM 4.1.10, Return Preparer Program Coordinator.

) Emerging issues can come in many forms. An emerging issue may have one or more of the following characteristics: a. It arises from a new or novel set of facts or through questions of the proper application of tax law. b. It has not been addressed by published legal guidance or administrative pronouncements of the Service. c. It is susceptible to inconsistent treatment by both the Service and LB&I taxpayers. d. It may or may not involve a potential abusive tax avoidance transaction. e. It is not necessarily limited to a speciﬁc industry and can impact across Service Divisions. (

) Tax issues can be identiﬁed by examiners, managers, specialists, subject matter experts, and other IRS personnel. Sources for identifying issues include, but are not limited to, current examinations, news articles, the Tax Shelter Hotline, taxpayer inquiries and industry contacts. Issues identiﬁed should be brought to the attention of the applicable Issue Practice Network as early as possible. (

) The reportable transaction category “transaction of interest” (TOI) is deﬁned as a transaction that the IRS and the Treasury Department believe is a transac- tion that has the potential for tax avoidance or evasion, but lack sufficient information to determine whether the transaction should be identiﬁed speciﬁ- cally as a tax avoidance transaction. The TOI category of reportable transactions will apply to transactions entered into on or after November

) Classiﬁcation is mandatory for any compliance programs approved by the Compliance Strategy Council with an issue-based audit treatment stream. ceptions to this requirement include returns that don’t require classiﬁcation, ″ ″ upon ad hoc approval by the Compliance Strategy Council ( CSC ). (
) The main functions, tools, and systems for classiﬁcation are (not • Content Management and Collaboration (CMC) • E-Classiﬁer
Other Workload Selection and Research – Non-Campaign Compliance Programs 4.50.2

) CMC is utilized for classifying and risking returns. CMC provides enhanced inventory management to CMC managers, leads and team members. CMC allows for cases to be assigned to a group, assigned to a speciﬁc team member and submitted for approval to the manager by the team member system generated e-mail alerting the appropriate person when an action is needed. CMC allows for cases to be automatically updated on AIMS when manager approves a case to be sent to the LWIS system for assignment to ﬁeld. Feedback is provided in the risk assessment form in CMC. (

) The E-Classiﬁer is a secured virtual and physical environment used for fying case work from large volumes of international data that must be to identify compliance issues, to support the case processing mission. The E-Classiﬁer tool enables classiﬁers access to a wide range of returns and works seamlessly within the classiﬁcation process. The E-Classiﬁer tool provides electronic feedback measurements from classiﬁers that identify compliant activity.

CMC is utilized for classifying and risking returns. CMC provides enhanced inventory management to CMC managers, leads and team members. CMC allows for cases to be assigned to a group, assigned to a speciﬁc team member and submitted for approval to the manager by the team member with system generated e-mail alerting the appropriate person when an action is needed. CMC allows for cases to be automatically updated on AIMS when the manager approves a case to be sent to the LWIS system for assignment to the ﬁeld. Feedback is provided in the risk assessment form in CMC.
